What Are Coral Reefs - Introduction

What do you think of when you hear the term "coral reef" or when someone asks "<a href="http://blog.stevenwsmeltzer.com/what-are-coral-reefs/"; title="What are Coral Reefs" target="_blank">What are coral reefs</a>?".. Some may think of the Great Barrier Reef in Australia while others may think of the reefs surrounding the <a href="http://www.stevenwsmeltzer.com/"; title="Scuba Diving the Caribbean" target="_blank">Caribbean islands</a> or yet someone else may think of aqua-blue water and long sandy beaches surrounding their favorite island or tropical get away.

<a href="http://stevenwsmeltzer.com/gallery/Coral-Reefs/G00007HdqcXifCa4/"; title="What Are Coral Reefs" target="_blank">Coral reefs</a> are definitely related to each of these but they are much, much more. Coral reefs are estimated to cover 284,300 km (109,800 sq mi), just under 0.1% of the oceans' surface area. The Indo-Pacific region (including the Red Sea, Indian Ocean, Southeast Asia and the <a href="http://stevenwsmeltzer.com/gallery/Hawaiian-Fish-Pictures/G0000nEnP4ApIAak/"; title="Pictures of Fish" target="_blank">Pacific</a> account for 91.9% of this total. Southeast Asia accounts for 32.3% of that figure, while the Pacific including Australia accounts for 40.8%. Atlantic and <a href="http://stevenwsmeltzer.com/gallery/Caribbean-Fish/G0000l7UPDDuOGA0/"; title="Pictures of Fish" target="_blank">Caribbean coral reefs</a> account for 7.6%.

This series of articles will focus on what are coral reefs and try to understand the importance of coral reefs to our environment. Some of the items that we will review includes:

Types of Coral Reefs
Benefits of Coral Reefs
Dangers to the Reefs
Economics impacts of Coral Reefs

Overview

Coral reefs form a critical part of the earth's overall ecosystem. While Coral reefs cover less than one tenth of one percent of the earth's oceans these same reefs are estimated to contain one quarter of known marine fish species. Scientists estimate that there could be anywhere from one to eight million undiscovered species living in and around the coral reefs (<a href="http://ocean.si.edu/ocean-life-ecosystems/coral-reefs"; title="Smithsonian Ocean Portal" target="_blank">Smithsonian Institute</a>.

The importance of this precious resource can not be </strong><strong>underestimated. Coral Reefs are critical to not only our ecosystem but also the world's financial system, through fishing and harvesting of marine plants and animals, the ability of the reefs to protect land masses from dangerous storms, providing moisture that in turn provides rain to all </strong><strong>of the earth's land masses, and much more. Without these reef systems our world would look much different than it does today.

Corals are tiny animals which belong to the group <em>cnidaria</em> (the "c" is silent). Other cnidarians include hydras, jellyfish, and <a href="http://stevenwsmeltzer.com/gallery-image/Crustaceans-and-Echinoderms/G0000OLcModvF7w4/I00000v7PLoc5Ld8"; title="Picture of Sea Anemone" target="_blank">sea anemones</a>. Corals are <em>sessile</em> animals, meaning they are not mobile but stay fixed in one place. As corals grow and expand, they will form one three reef types:

Fringing
Barrier or
Atoll

Fringing reefs: These are the most common types of coral reefs and they project seaward directly from the shore, forming borders along the shoreline and surrounding islands.
Barrier reefs: These reefs also border shorelines, but at a greater distance. They are separated from their adjacent land mass by a lagoon of open, often relatively deep stretch of water.
Atoll: These reefs form when a fringing reef forms around a volcanic island and continues to grow upward while the volcanic island subsides completely below sea level. Atolls are usually circular or oval, with a central lagoon. Parts of the reef platform may emerge as one or more islands, and breaks in the reef provide access to the central lagoon

All three reef types of coral reefsâ€”<a href="http://stevenwsmeltzer.com/gallery-image/Coral-Reefs/G00007HdqcXifCa4/I0000OYLGxeWpsD0"; title="Lagoon Zone" target="_blank">fringing, barrier and atoll</a>â€”share similarities in their biogeographic profiles. Their bottom topography, depth, wave, current strength, light, temperature, and amount of suspended sediments act to create horizontal and vertical zones of corals, algae and other species. While these zones vary according to the location and type of reef, there are a number of major divisions which are common to most reefs, as they move seaward from the shore, including the reef flat, reef crest or algal ridge, buttress zone, and seaward slope.

Through this series of articles we will answer the following questions:

What are Coral Reefs?
Where are Coral Reefs located and How were they formed?
What are the different types of Coral Reefs?
What types of <a href="http://www.stevenwsmeltzer.com/"; title="Underwater Photography and Marine Species Information" target="_blank">creatures inhabit coral reefs</a>?
What are the threats to Coral Reefs?
What are the potential impacts of these threats on us from the impacts to our economy, to food supplies, to medicines and more
What if anything should we be doing to help the coral reefs?
How can you help?

So come join in the <a href="http://www.stevenwsmeltzer.com/"; title="Pictures of Coral Reefs" target="_blank">discovery of our coral reefs</a> and the<a href="http://stevenwsmeltzer.com/gallery/Underwater-World-StevenWSmeltzer-com/G0000rThUYFy4ACc/"; title="Underwater World Pictures" target="_blank"> underwater world </a>that is so amazing and important to each and everyone one of us.

Educators, send your schools name, address, the title to your class, and your grade level and I will provide you with an invitation only access to special galleries where you can download images to share with your classrooms. When you send your request make sure to send a copy of your logo and also contact information for your school including email address and phone number.
Next week...What are Coral Reefs - Introduction to the Underwater World

Scuba Diving Grand Cayman - Dragon's Hole

Overall Rating - 2.7 out of 5

<a href="http://blog.stevenwsmeltzer.com/dive-site-reviews-and-listings/dive-sites/scuba-diving-grand-cayman-dragons-hole/?preview=true&preview_id=2556&preview_nonce=4a2598423b"; title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank">Scuba diving Dragon's Hole</a> can be quite a varied experience. I don't dive on this site very often and on most dives it is average at best when compared with the other <a href="http://www.stevenwsmeltzer.com"; title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank">wall dives</a> on the west side. I much prefer, Hepp's Wall, Northwest Point, <a href="http://blog.stevenwsmeltzer.com/dive-site-reviews-and-listings/dive-sites/scuba-diving-grand-cayman-orange-canyon/"; title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank">Orange Canyon</a>, Bonnie's Arch, or even <a href="http://blog.stevenwsmeltzer.com/dive-site-reviews-and-listings/dive-sites/scuba-diving-grand-cayman-big-tunnels/"; title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank">Big Tunnels</a>. If you cannot dive one of these scuba diving sites there, I would recommend asking the boat captain to head back to Round Rock or Trinity Caves. I have found over a number of years that these sites tend to be the best on the west side. The current is always a consideration but Hepp's Wall, Bonnie's Arch and Northwest Point are some of the <a href="http://blog.stevenwsmeltzer.com/dive-site-reviews-and-listings/"; title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank">best dives on Grand Cayman</a> so don't miss them if you get a chance.

That said Dragon's Hole can still be a very good dive depending upon the current and the amount of particulates in the water. This dive site tends to be a bit more "cloudy" than other wall dive sites on the west end of Grand Cayman but still has a lot of good features. Backscatter can be a real problem so if you are an underwater photographer or if you are just trying to get a few photos to show friends back home, remember to keep your strobes very wide on this scuba diving site or you could end up with a lot of photos that are not worth printing. This is definitely better as a "first/deep" <a href="http://stevenwsmeltzer.photoshelter.com/gallery/Scuba-Diving-Grand-Cayman/G0000DLsGbyx7U5k/"; title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank">dive</a> and is typical of other scuba diving sites on the west side. You will find a number of <a href="http://stevenwsmeltzer.photoshelter.com/gallery/Sponges/G0000AUYkLv.mB8M/"; title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank">Orange Elephant Ear</a> sponges along with Roe Pore Rope sponges, brain corals and numerous other soft and hard corals along with a good variety of fish. The <a href="http://stevenwsmeltzer.photoshelter.com/gallery/Coral-Reefs/G00007HdqcXifCa4/"; title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank">coral condition</a> on the site is fair to average but on top of the wall the condition of the coral would be a bit less than average especially if compared with the scuba diving sites on the north side of the island.

On our last dive we found several <a href="http://stevenwsmeltzer.photoshelter.com/gallery-image/Caribbean-Fish/G0000l7UPDDuOGA0/I00004r6Kk2jcPkA"; title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank">Lionfish</a> and one of the dive masters promptly dispatched them. While some people may feel some angst about killing these fish, it is something that must be done. Lionfish are definitely a danger to the Caribbean and other areas since these fish have few if any <a href="http://stevenwsmeltzer.photoshelter.com/gallery-image/Caribbean-Fish/G0000l7UPDDuOGA0/I0000Rp.i4F6rXf8"; title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank">natural predators</a> in the Caribbean. These fish are voracious hunters and could significantly impact the reefs if not dealt with now. So if you do not like this, please do not hinder the work of the divers. It is important.

I have gotten some amazing shots on this sites including this <a href="http://stevenwsmeltzer.photoshelter.com/gallery-image/Caribbean-Fish/G0000l7UPDDuOGA0/I00005Ta8Y0MP5DE"; title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank">Green Moray Eel</a>. So my advice is to take this site as a second or third choice, but if you do dive on this site, please enjoy it as you never know quite what you may find.

<a title="StevenWSmeltzer.com" href="http://www.stevenwsmeltzer.com">The pool is open.....</a>

Scuba Diving Grand Cayman - Penny's Arch

Overall Rating 4.2 out of 5

<a href="http://www.stevenwsmeltzer.com/"; title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank">Scuba Diving</a> on <a href="http://blog.stevenwsmeltzer.com/dive-site-reviews-and-listings/dive-sites/scuba-diving-grand-cayman-pennys-arch/"; title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank">Penny's Arch</a> is usually great dive. It is almost directly across from Rum Point and in a place that does not get high traffic, but is still within the typical "west side" dive operators range. This <a href="http://stevenwsmeltzer.com/gallery/Scuba-Diving-Grand-Cayman/G0000DLsGbyx7U5k/"; title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank">scuba diving site</a> has a nice archway, hence the name, and has a very nice coral garden at the top of the reef. The dive site is typical for those on the north wall and this far to the east the coral reef really looks good. When the water is clear, which is most of the time, this site can be really great. The wall is spectacular as usual and you have a great chance to sea Spotted Eagle Rays, turtles, numerous <a href="http://stevenwsmeltzer.com/gallery/Caribbean-Fish/G0000l7UPDDuOGA0/"; title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank">Caribbean fish</a> and maybe even sharks on this site.

You will start down by the buoy and then start making you will down through a cut in the coral and then swim down and through Penny's Arch. Do not worry it is very wide. You will then be emerge on the wall and swim along the wall for a bit before returning to the top of the wall to explore the coral gardens. If you are into <a href="http://stevenwsmeltzer.com/gallery/Scuba-Diving-Underwater-Photography/G0000BWCcQG1I0II/"; title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank">underwater photography</a> look back and up as you emerge from the arch and you can typically get some very nice wall shots looking up at towards the sun (assuming the sun is shinning). You can get a great sense of the deep trench that surrounds Grand Cayman as you gaze downward into the blue for literally hundreds of feet. The sense is surreal and I love this view.

The <a href="http://stevenwsmeltzer.com/gallery/Coral-Reefs/G00007HdqcXifCa4/"; title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank">coral reef </a>is quite good on this dive site. It gets plenty of nutrients and is far enough away from the cuts in the reef by the North Sound that you don't usually have a problem with visibility even after a rain. It can get cloudy like any other site, but the visibility here is usually excellent.

When finishing up your dive in the coral, make sure to look carefully, usually you will find a good number of spiny lobsters, moray eels, quite a variety of fish, as well as a large variety of <a href="http://stevenwsmeltzer.com/gallery-image/Coral-Reefs/G00007HdqcXifCa4/I0000G5qZzU0DX7k"; title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank">soft and hard corals</a>. The Slimy Sea Plumes, Bent Sea Rods, Common Sea fans, Giant Slit-pore Sea Rods, and much more. On the<a href="http://stevenwsmeltzer.com/gallery/Coral-Reefs/G00007HdqcXifCa4/"; title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank"> Gorgonian fans</a>, you will usually find the colorful Flamingo Tongue snails, but be careful to leave them alone as the color on the shell is from a membrane that can be extended and retracted. When taken from the water these shells are just basic white with no color at all. You can find a great variety of <a href="" title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank">crustaceans</a> on the site, you just need to go slowly.

We found several <a href="http://stevenwsmeltzer.photoshelter.com/gallery-image/Caribbean-Fish/G0000l7UPDDuOGA0/I0000dlv7fuoJCBw"; title="Scuba Diving Grand Cayman" target="_blank">Lionfish</a> on the site, reminding everyone of the need to cull these fish so that they do not cause anymore damage to the local environment. <a title="StevenWSmeltzer.com" href="http://www.stevenwsmeltzer.com">The pool is open.....</a>
